node.title: Substack Expands Food Newsletters With Ruth Reichl and Others
node.alt: Ruth Reichl is tackling yet another form of food journalism.
node.description: The former restaurant critic and Gourmet editor is joining a cadre of chefs and authors enlisted to expand the platform’s culinary content.
node.content: ["Ruth Reichl has practiced food journalism in nearly every form imaginable. She\u2019s gone from a job as restaurant critic at a weekly California magazine to a similar post at The New York Times. She\u2019s held the top editing spot at Gourmet magazine, written memoirs, produced television shows and once served as editorial adviser to Gilt Taste, which sold luxury food.", "Now she is jumping into direct-to-consumer newsletters as part of a new push by the digital newsletter platform Substack to go deep on food writing.", "Ms. Reichl has committed to producing a month\u2019s worth of free daily newsletters as a writer in residence. If the project takes off and she likes the process, she will begin a newsletter that requires a subscription.", "Ms. Reichl joins a collection of food writers who will debut Dec. 1 as part of what the platform is calling \u201cSubstack Food.\u201d", "Food is the second specialized subject the company is taking on, using handpicked writers. The first, announced last summer, was comic books, with newsletters from a group of creators selected by the comic-book writer Nick Spencer.", "Substack already is home to several food writers \u2014 some who charge a subscription fee and others who write free newsletters. \u201cThe food writers are having a good time and thriving, and we want to see more of it,\u201d said Hamish McKenzie, a founder of Substack. \u201cIt\u2019s not like food-writer jobs are proliferating or people are getting bigger and bigger deals in books.\u201d", "The new group was assembled by Dan Stone, a journalist and bar owner who is the head of writer partnerships for Substack. The writers include well-known names like the TV personality Andrew Zimmern and the chef Andy Ricker, who will be writing from his home in Thailand, as well as lesser-known cooks like Alexis deBoschnek, a former test-kitchen manager at BuzzFeed who will produce a newsletter from her farm in the Catskill Mountains.", "For writers like Mr. Zimmern, who will charge $6 a month or $50 a year, the appeal is making a more direct connection to his large audience with recipes and travel tips, with room to delve into topics of the day and global issues.", "\u201cThis is a printed version of drive-time radio,\u201d said Mr. Zimmern, who once hosted such a show.", "Substack writers make money in one of two ways: Either they give Substack 10 percent of subscription revenue and are allowed to own their content and subscriber list, or they agree to a yearlong contract for a negotiated amount, allowing Substack to keep 85 percent of subscription money. (Anyone can produce a free newsletter on the platform.)", "There is big money to be made on Substack. The top 10 authors, who include the journalist Andrew Sullivan, the historian Heather Cox Richardson and the podcaster and author Matthew C. Taibbi, collectively make more than $20 million a year,", "Ms. Reichl\u2019s newsletter will be a mix of short essays, restaurant reviews and gift guides. She\u2019ll tap her archive of restaurant menus and articles (from the days before journalism was digitized) to produce what will essentially be a small daily magazine, edited by the radio host and cookbook editor Francis Lam.", "\u201cThere\u2019s a huge interest in food right now, and most of the stuff that\u2019s available is focused very much on recipes,\u201d Ms. Reichl said. \u201cThere are not a lot of places for thoughtful food coverage. Food is about so much more than recipes and restaurant reviews. It\u2019s a really important part of culture.\u201d", "Follow NYT Food on Twitter and NYT Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice."]
